original_title: Sri Lanka officials discuss next steps in electricity reform
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Government officials and foreign consultants have met to discuss the next steps in Sri Lanka’s electricity sector reform process.
On Monday, the cabinet of ministers granted approval for the proposed new reforms of the Ceylon Electricity Board and the new electricity bill to be tabled in Parliament for approval.
“I met with the officials of the reform secretariat yesterday to discuss the next steps in the electricity sector reform process,” Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said.

“ADB has recruited and extended the services of Dr Pankaj Batra, former Chairman of the Central Electricity Authority of India to assist the Reform Secretariat on the National System Operator, Prof Arosha Adikaram, Chair of the Human Resources Department, University of Colombo to assist on the Human Resource Management of CEB and Mr Debasis Mohapatra, Executive ADB consultant on institutional strengthening.

“We discussed the observations made by the president, cabinet ministers, development agencies such as ADB, JICA, World Bank, USAID, the inclusion of regulations necessary for a smooth transition, consumer protection laws, constitutional requirements, tariff regulations and amendments to the Sinhala draft bill necessary before gazetting and presenting in parliament for approval.”
The proposed bill aims to split the Ceylon Electricity Board into four distribution companies, CEB thermal plants into one and hydro plants into another.
CEB’s hydro plants will be a 100 percent state-run firm which will not be divested.
There will be a transmission company and the system control, which will do procurement.
It may take up to three years for asset audits to be completed and wholesale markets to be set up, Wijesekera said previously. (Colombo/Nov23/2023)
